Package projects.spatial.nodes

Class PRQuadNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.spatial.nodes.PRQuadNode
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    PRQuadBlackNode, PRQuadGrayNode
    public abstract class PRQuadNode
extends java.lang.Object

    PRQuadNode is an abstract class used to provide the common structure that all implementing subclasses will share. It is an abstraction over nodes of a Point-Region (PR)- QuadTree. Consult the lecture slides and the textbook to review the different kinds of nodes in a PR-QuadTree, what they should contain and how they should implement insertion and deletion.

    YOU SHOULD ***NOT*** EDIT THIS CLASS! If you do, you risk not passing our tests!

    Author:
    Jason Filippou

    • Field Detail

      • INFTY

        public static final java.math.BigDecimal INFTY
        A named constant representing infinity.

      • centroid

        protected KDPoint centroid
        The centroid of the current node. Its dimensions allow us to direct incoming KDPoints to the appropriate subtree. INVARIANT: centroid != null
        See Also:
        k

      • k

        protected int k

        The exponent to which 2 (two) is raised to characterize the length of the current quadrant's size. For example, if k=4, the length of the quadrant that is "spanned" by the current PRQuadNode is 2^4 = 16. If we were to temporarily consider the current quadrant as being a mini version of POSITIVE cartesian space (so, the upper right quadrant of all those function graphs that we learned to make in middle / high school, that has only positive 'x's and 'y's), then the centroid of the quadrant would have coordinates (8, 8). In general, it would have coordinates ( 2^(k-1), 2^(k-1) ).

        It is also possible for this parameter to be negative. This will just mean that the produced quadrant will have a size length equal to negative powers of 2, such as -1/2, -1/8, etc. This is completely fine with respect to the type KDPoint, which has double accuracy and can fit KDPoint instances whose coordinates are non-integer numbers.

        Given this parameter, you can probably imagine implementations that do not require using the parameter centroid. It is completely fine if you do not want to use this parameter at all: we are just including it there because we feel your code will be cleaner if you do.

        See Also:
        centroid

      • bucketingParam

        protected int bucketingParam
        The bucketing parameter of the PRQuadTree. Necessary for all derived classes such that merges and splits can be determined on the fly.

    • Constructor Detail

      • PRQuadNode

        protected PRQuadNode​(KDPoint centroid,
                     int k,
                     int bucketingParam)
        protected constructor. Every PRQuadNode, at the very minimum, requires information about the dimensions of the quadrant it spans, its current centroid (which is computable from the dimensions, yet allows for a cleaner and slightly more efficient implementation) and the bucketing parameter.
        Parameters:
        centroid - A KDPoint that represents the center of the space spanned by the current node.
        k - The exponent to which 2 is raised to characterize the side length of the quadrant " spanned " by this. Refer to PRQuadTree(int, int) for a more thorough explanation of how the parameter k works.
        bucketingParam - The bucketing parameter of the tree. Necessary so that we can store the parameter in freshly created PRQuadBlackNodes!
        See Also:
        KDPoint, PRQuadBlackNode(KDPoint, int, int), PRQuadBlackNode(KDPoint, int, int, KDPoint), PRQuadGrayNode(KDPoint, int, int)

    • Method Detail

      • insert

        public abstract PRQuadNode insert​(KDPoint p,
                                  int k)
        Inserts the given point in the subtree rooted at the current node. Returns the updated subtree.
        Parameters:
        p - A KDPoint to insert into the subtree rooted at the current node.
        k - The side length of the quadrant spanned by the current PRQuadNode. It is important that this value is updated per recursive call, such that the recursively generated quadrants have the appropriate side length and can drive KDPoints to the appropriate children nodes!
        Returns:
        The subtree rooted at the current node, potentially adjusted after insertion.

      • delete

        public abstract PRQuadNode delete​(KDPoint p)
        Deletes the given point from the subtree rooted at the current node. If the point is not in the subtree, no changes should be performed in the subtree.
        Parameters:
        p - A KDPoint to delete from the tree rooted at the current node.
        Returns:
        The subtree rooted at the current node, potentially adjusted after deletion.

      • search

        public abstract boolean search​(KDPoint p)
        Searches the subtree rooted at the current node for the provided KDPoint.
        Parameters:
        p - The KDPoint to search for.
        Returns:
        true if p was found in the subtree rooted at the current nodes, false otherwise.

      • height

        public abstract int height()
        Return the height of the subtree rooted at the current nodes. The height is defined similarly to AVL trees, as follows:
        1. The height of a null tree (no nodes) is -1 (minus 1).
        2. The height of a tree that consists of a single node (a "stub" tree) is 0 (zero).
        3. The height of a tree that consists of four children is the maximum height of its children plus one.

        Returns:
        the height of the subtree rooted at the current node.

      • count

        public abstract int count()
        Return the total number of KDPoints contained in the subtree rooted at the current node.
        Returns:
        the total number of KDPoints contained in the subtree rooted at the current node.

        range - The radius of the range query.

        true if the circle generated by the range query

      • range

        public abstract void range​(KDPoint anchor,
                           java.util.Collection<KDPoint> results,
                           java.math.BigDecimal range)

        Executes a range query in the given PRQuadNode. Given an "anchor" KDPoint, all KDPoints that have a distanceSquared of at most range INCLUSIVE from the anchor point except for the anchor itself should be inserted into the Collection that is passed.

        Remember: range queries behave greedily as we go down (approaching the anchor as "fast" as our currDim allows and prune subtrees that we don't have to visit as we backtrack. Consult all of our resources if you need a reminder of how these should work.

        Finally, note that the range parameter is a Euclidean Distance, not the square of a Euclidean Distance!

        Parameters:
        anchor - The centroid of the hypersphere that the range query implicitly creates.
        results - A Collection that accumulates all the
        range - The INCLUSIVE range from the "anchor" KDPoint, within which all the KDPoints that satisfy our query will fall. The distanceSquared metric used} is defined by KDPoint.distanceSquared(KDPoint).

      • nearestNeighbor

        public abstract NNData<KDPoint> nearestNeighbor​(KDPoint anchor,
                                                NNData<KDPoint> n)

        Executes a nearest neighbor query, which returns the nearest neighbor, in terms of KDPoint.distanceSquared(KDPoint), from the "anchor" point.

        Recall that, in the descending phase, a NN query behaves greedily, approaching our "anchor" point as fast as currDim allows. While doing so, it implicitly bounds the acceptable solutions under the current best solution, which is passed as an argument. This approach is known in Computer Science as "branch-and-bound" and it helps us solve an otherwise exponential complexity problem (nearest neighbors) efficiently. Remember that when we want to determine if we need to recurse to a different subtree, it is necessary to compare the distanceSquared reported by KDPoint.distanceSquared(KDPoint) and coordinate differences! Those are comparable with each other because they are the same data type (Double).

        Parameters:
        anchor - The "ancor" KDPointof the nearest neighbor query.
        n - An object of type NNData, which will define a nearest neighbor as a pair (distance_of_NN_from_anchor, NN), * where NN is the nearest neighbor found.
        Returns:
        An object of type NNData, which exposes the pair (distance_of_NN_from_anchor, NN), where NN is the nearest KDPoint to the anchor KDPoint that we found.
        See Also:
        NNData, kNearestNeighbors(int, KDPoint, BoundedPriorityQueue)

      • kNearestNeighbors

        public abstract void kNearestNeighbors​(int k,
                                       KDPoint anchor,
                                       BoundedPriorityQueue<KDPoint> queue)

        Executes a nearest neighbor query, which returns the nearest neighbor, in terms of KDPoint.distanceSquared(KDPoint), from the "anchor" point.

        Recall that, in the descending phase, a NN query behaves greedily, approaching our "anchor" point as fast as currDim allows. While doing so, it implicitly bounds the acceptable solutions under the current worst solution, which is maintained as the last element of the provided BoundedPriorityQueue. This is another instance of "branch-and-bound" Remember that when we want to determine if we need to recurse to a different subtree, it is necessary to compare the distanceSquared reported by* KDPoint.distanceSquared(KDPoint) and coordinate differences! Those are comparable with each other because they are the same data type (Double).

        The main difference of the implementation of this method and the implementation of nearestNeighbor(KDPoint, NNData) is the necessity of using the class BoundedPriorityQueue effectively. Consult your various resources to understand how you should be using this class.

        Parameters:
        k - The total number of neighbors to retrieve. It is better if this quantity is an odd number, to avoid ties in Binary Classification tasks.
        anchor - The "anchor" KDPoint of the nearest neighbor query.
        queue - A BoundedPriorityQueue that will maintain at most k nearest neighbors of the anchor point at all times, sorted by distanceSquared to the point.
        See Also:
        BoundedPriorityQueue
